[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#bodyContent)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Regional political movement in Italy

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Flag_of_Republic_of_Venice_%281659-1675%29.svg/250px-Flag_of_Republic_of_Venice_%281659-1675%29.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Flag_of_Republic_of_Venice_(1659-1675).svg) [Flag of the Republic of Venice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_the_Republic_of_Venice "Flag of the Republic of Venice")[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Variant_war_flag_of_the_Serene_Republic_of_Venice.svg/250px-Variant_war_flag_of_the_Serene_Republic_of_Venice.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Variant_war_flag_of_the_Serene_Republic_of_Venice.svg) War flag of the Republic of Venice[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Flag_of_Veneto.svg/250px-Flag_of_Veneto.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Flag_of_Veneto.svg) [Flag of Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Veneto "Flag of Veneto")

**Venetian nationalism** (also **Venetism**,[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-1) from the [Venetian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_language "Venetian language")/ [Italian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language") name, _venetismo_) is a [nationalist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nationalism "Nationalism"), but primarily [regionalist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regionalism_(politics) "Regionalism (politics)"), political movement active mostly in [Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veneto "Veneto"), [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy "Italy"), as well as in other parts of the former [Republic of Venice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Venice "Republic of Venice").

Generally speaking, Venetists promote the distinct Venetian identity and the rediscovery of the Republic of Venice's heritage, traditions, culture, and language and/or demand more autonomy or even independence for Veneto from Italy.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-4) According to journalist [Paolo Possamai](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Paolo_Possamai&action=edit&redlink=1 "Paolo Possamai (page does not exist)"), Venetism is "the strain of Veneto and Venetians toward the recognition of their identity and autonomy".[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-5) Venetism is a broad movement,[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-6) which definitely includes Venetist parties, notably [Liga Veneta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_Veneta "Liga Veneta"), but also encompasses people from several political parties. In 1982 [Goffredo Parise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goffredo_Parise "Goffredo Parise"), a writer and journalist, wrote: "Veneto is my fatherland. \[...\] Even if a Republic of Italy exists, this abstract idea is not my Fatherland \[...\]. We Venetians have travelled throughout the world, but our Fatherland, that for which we would fight if it were necessary to fight, is Veneto. \[...\] When I see "River sacred to the Fatherland" written on the bridges spanning the [Piave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piave_(river) "Piave (river)"), I am moved, not because I think of Italy, but rather because I think of Veneto."[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-7)[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-8)

Most Venetists consider Veneto a nation distinct from Italy and some refuse the validity of the result of the referendum through which Veneto (or, better, _Venetia_) was united with Italy in 1866.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Beggiato-9)[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Borsetto-10)[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-11)[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-12) Some of them have long proposed a re-edition of that referendum and campaign for the independence of _Venetia_, a country that would be composed of the territories of the historical Venetian Republic, covering Veneto, [Friuli-Venezia Giulia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friuli-Venezia_Giulia "Friuli-Venezia Giulia"), and large chunks of [Lombardy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lombardy "Lombardy") (the [province of Brescia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Brescia "Province of Brescia"), the [province of Bergamo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Bergamo "Province of Bergamo"), the area around [Crema](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crema,_Lombardy "Crema, Lombardy") and a portion of the [province of Mantua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Mantua "Province of Mantua")).[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-13) The proposal, regarding to Veneto alone, has more recently gained the support of Liga Veneta, the [Government of Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Veneto "Government of Veneto"), and the majority of the [Regional Council of Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Council_of_Veneto "Regional Council of Veneto"), which endorsed a bill aimed at organising the referendum in 2014. The [Constitutional Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Italy "Constitutional Court of Italy") ruled that referendum out as contrary to the [Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy "Constitution of Italy"), but authorised an [autonomy referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Venetian_autonomy_referendum "2017 Venetian autonomy referendum"), which took place on 22 October 2017: 57.2% of Venetians participated in the referendum and 98.1% voted "yes". Consequently, [President of Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_Veneto "President of Veneto") [Luca Zaia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luca_Zaia "Luca Zaia") started a negotiation with the Italian government.

Although it usually refers to the whole Venetian autonomist movement,[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-14) the term "Venetism" is sometimes used to identify specifically culture-oriented Venetists, hardline Venetists or those Venetists who refuse the concept of [Padania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Padania "Padania"), a proposed country by [Lega Nord](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lega_Nord "Lega Nord") / [Lega](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lega_(political_party) "Lega (political party)"), of which Liga Veneta (the most successful Venetist party so far) has been the "national/regional" section in Veneto. [Alberto Gardin](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Alberto_Gardin&action=edit&redlink=1 "Alberto Gardin (page does not exist)"), a pro-independence publisher and later self proclaimed 121st Doge[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-15) who supports the boycott of Italian elections, offers another interpretation by considering "Venetism" a "partisan concept, that is part of the Italian political system (Venetists, as [Socialists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Socialist_Party "Italian Socialist Party"), [Communists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Communist_Party "Italian Communist Party"), [PD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Italy) "Democratic Party (Italy)"), [PdL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_People_of_Freedom "The People of Freedom"), etc.)".[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-16)

## Background and history

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Background and history")\]

### Annexation of Veneto by Italy

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Annexation of Veneto by Italy")\]

The [Venetian Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Venice "Republic of Venice") existed for 1100 years from 697 to 1797 (submitted to [Byzantium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byzantium "Byzantium") until the 9th century), and was one of the first modern republics of the world. After defeating the [Republic of Genoa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa "Republic of Genoa") in a [series of wars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian%E2%80%93Genoese_wars "Venetian–Genoese wars"), it became the most powerful [Mediterranean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea") maritime power, and at its height, extended its rule from large parts of the [Po Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Po_Valley "Po Valley") to the coastal regions and islands of present-day [Slovenia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slovenia "Slovenia"), [Croatia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatia "Croatia"), [Bosnia and Herzegovina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina"), [Montenegro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montenegro "Montenegro"), [Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania "Albania"), and [Greece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greece "Greece"). Venice was a leading power of the Western world in the 15th and 16th centuries. In 1797, after a long decline, through the [Treaty of Campo Formio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Campo_Formio "Treaty of Campo Formio"), [Napoleon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napoleon "Napoleon") traded what remained of the Republic with Austria in exchange for other territories. In 1848, Venetians, led by [Daniele Manin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniele_Manin "Daniele Manin"), rebelled against Austrian rule and established the [Republic of San Marco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_San_Marco "Republic of San Marco"). Manin, who opposed the proposed unification by some Venetians with the [Kingdom of Sardinia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sardinia "Kingdom of Sardinia"), resigned, but returned to lead again the opposition against Vienna in 1849.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Minahan-17)

Venetian territories with the former Duchy of Mantua and Friuli were annexed to Italy in 1866, five years after the [Italian unification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_unification "Italian unification") and the creation of the [Kingdom of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy "Kingdom of Italy") under the [House of Savoy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Savoy "House of Savoy") in 1861. The unification of Veneto with Italy was the result of the [Austro-Prussian War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austro-Prussian_War "Austro-Prussian War"), won by the [Prussians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prussia "Prussia"), Italy's allies. In the Italian unification process, the conflict is known as [Third War of Independence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_Italian_War_of_Independence "Third Italian War of Independence"). Austria lost Venetia, ceded to [Napoleon III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napoleon_III "Napoleon III") of France, who in turn ceded it to Italy. Austria refused to give Venetian territories directly to Italy because the Austrians had crushed the Italians during the war, defeating the Italians on land during the [Battle of Custoza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Custoza_(1866) "Battle of Custoza (1866)") (24 June) and on sea during the [Battle of Lissa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Lissa_(1866) "Battle of Lissa (1866)") (20 July). [Giuseppe Garibaldi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giuseppe_Garibaldi "Giuseppe Garibaldi")'s [Hunters of the Alps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunters_of_the_Alps "Hunters of the Alps") had some success against the Austrians at the [Battle of Bezzecca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Bezzecca "Battle of Bezzecca") (21 July), but the Italian government ordered Garibaldi to withdraw when Prussia and Austria concluded an armistice. With the [Peace of Prague](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_of_Prague_(1866) "Peace of Prague (1866)") (23 August), Austria agreed to the incorporation of Venetia in the Kingdom of Italy. The same point was repeated in the [Treaty of Vienna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Vienna_(1866) "Treaty of Vienna (1866)") (12 October), achieved through the mediation of France.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-18)

The Venetian territory was first ceded by Austria to France (under a treaty signed by General [Karl Moering](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Karl_Moering&action=edit&redlink=1 "Karl Moering (page does not exist)"), on behalf of [Franz Joseph I of Austria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franz_Joseph_I_of_Austria "Franz Joseph I of Austria"), and General [Edmond Le Bœuf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmond_Le_B%C5%93uf "Edmond Le Bœuf"), on behalf of Napoleon III) as a compensation for French neutrality during the war. According to the treaty, France ceded Venetia to Italy "under the reservation of the consent of the people duly consulted". Whether an option other than becoming Italian was available was unclear, nor was the treaty any more precise on how to consult the people. Venetia was already under Italian control after the French government renounced to it on 19 October.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-19)

This increases doubts on the real importance of the [plebiscite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plebiscite_of_Veneto_of_1866 "Plebiscite of Veneto of 1866") and leading historians suggest that the referendum in Venetia was held under military pressure,[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-20) as a mere 0.01% of voters (69 out of more than 642,000 ballots) voted against the annexation and a mere 0.1% (567 ballots) was null, and that it was ultimately [rigged](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electoral_fraud "Electoral fraud").[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Beggiato-9)[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Borsetto-10)[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-21) Some historians, who investigated into the historical archive of the Austrian foreign ministry, also suggest that the referendum was a mere administrative affair to Italy, just to formalise the sovereignty on a territory already under its possession, and that no real choice nor free vote was granted to the local population.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-22) The plebiscite could have been a mere demonstration[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-23) to gain legitimacy after the bad conduct of Italy during the so-called Third War of Independence.

The Kingdom of Italy adopted Italian as the official language. Venetians, similarly to several other regional communities, largely rejected that and continued to use their own [Venetian language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_language "Venetian language"), often dubbed as dialect.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] Linguistic nationalism soon started to be part of Venetian culture, and during the last decades of the 19th century, also some revolts against [southern Italian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Italy "Southern Italy") bureaucrats occurred.\[ _[when?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_\]\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] After its incorporation to Italy, Venetia was so poor that millions of Venetians had to emigrate toward the [Americas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americas "Americas"), especially [Brazil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazil "Brazil") and [Argentina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentina "Argentina") (three millions left their homeland from 1870 and 1910),[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-24)[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-25)[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-26)[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-27) without losing their heritage, so even today, many Venetian descendants in [Latin America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America"), most notably in two Brazilian southern states, [Rio Grande do Sul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_Grande_do_Sul "Rio Grande do Sul") and [Santa Catarina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state) "Santa Catarina (state)"), speak Venetian as their mother tongue.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Minahan-17)

### World Wars and the Italian Republic

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: World Wars and the Italian Republic")\]

Right after [World War I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), the economic and political situation in Veneto was critical, so that a former [Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Italy "Prime Minister of Italy") and native of [Venice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venice "Venice"), [Luigi Luzzatti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luigi_Luzzatti "Luigi Luzzatti"), wrote to Prime Minister [Vittorio Emanuele Orlando](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vittorio_Emanuele_Orlando "Vittorio Emanuele Orlando") and told him there could be a "Venetian Ireland", in parallel to the simultaneous [Irish War of Independence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_War_of_Independence "Irish War of Independence"), while the prefect of [Treviso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treviso "Treviso") signalled the risk that a separatist movement aimed at separating Veneto from Italy might flourish in the province of [Treviso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Treviso "Province of Treviso").[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Beggiato.itgo-28)[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-OntheNord-29)[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Luzzatti-30)

Precursors of the present-day Venetist movement date back to before [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and were both left- and right-wing. In 1920 _La Riscossa_, a Venetian newspaper close to the [Socialists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Socialist_Party "Italian Socialist Party") and the [Republicans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Republican_Party "Italian Republican Party"), espoused the need for a "united elective governorate with autonomous and competent technical and administrative organs" as an alternative to the "central political rule"[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-31) [Guido Bergamo](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Guido_Bergamo&action=edit&redlink=1 "Guido Bergamo (page does not exist)"), a Republican member of the Chamber of Deputies elected in Veneto, wrote that "the Venetian problem is so acute that from today on we will preach the rebellion of Venetians. Citizens, let's not pay taxes, not recognise the central government in Rome, chase away prefects, retain the money from direct taxes in Veneto".[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Beggiato.itgo-28)[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-OntheNord-29)[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Luzzatti-30)[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-32) Shortly after [Italico Corradino Cappellotto](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Italico_Corradino_Cappellotto&action=edit&redlink=1 "Italico Corradino Cappellotto (page does not exist)"), a member of the Chamber of Deputies for the [Italian People's Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_People%27s_Party_(1919) "Italian People's Party (1919)"), launched the first Venetist party forth of the [1921 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1921_Italian_general_election "1921 Italian general election"): the [Lion of Saint Mark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lion_of_Saint_Mark_(political_party) "Lion of Saint Mark (political party)") won 6.1% of the votes in the province of Treviso.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Francesco_Jori_2009,_pp._35,_41-33)[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Toffano-34)

After the [takeover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/March_on_Rome "March on Rome") of [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini"), who among other things proposed to eradicate the local languages in favour of Italian language widespread, the rise of Fascism, World War II, and the birth of the [Italian Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Italian_Republic "History of the Italian Republic"), Venetist ideas lost ground, in an era in which the "myth of the indivisibility and the unity" of the country was strong even in Veneto.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Toffano-34) However, the campaign of Mussolini to eradicate regional languages was largely unsuccessful in the region,[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Minahan-17) which soon became a stronghold of the [Christian Democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democracy_(Italy) "Christian Democracy (Italy)") (DC) party due to the leading role of the [Catholic Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") in the region.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-35) In the [1948 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1948_Italian_general_election_in_Veneto "1948 Italian general election in Veneto") Christian Democrats won 60.5% of the vote in Veneto.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-36)

Since 1919, Venetia plus the newly annexed territories from Austria, which included [Trentino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trentino "Trentino") and [South Tyrol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Tyrol "South Tyrol"), were called the Three Venices ( _Tre Venezie_, whereof _[Triveneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triveneto "Triveneto")_), meaning _Venezia Euganea_ ( [Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veneto "Veneto") plus large chunks of [Friuli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friuli "Friuli")), _Venezia Giulia_ (the eastern part of current [Friuli-Venezia Giulia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friuli-Venezia_Giulia "Friuli-Venezia Giulia")) and _Venezia Tridentina_ (Trentino and South Tyrol).[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Minahan-17) However, under the [Constitution of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy "Constitution of Italy") adopted in 1948, only [Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trentino-Alto_Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol "Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol") and Friuli-Venezia Giulia were granted of the status of [special-statute autonomous region](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_regions_with_special_statute "Autonomous regions with special statute") and the connected special privileges, mainly including fiscal autonomy. Hence, the proposals by some groups of unifying Veneto with the two regions cited above (or with Trentino alone)[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-37) or giving also Veneto an autonomous statute.

### Comeback of Venetist ideas

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Comeback of Venetist ideas")\]

For more details on Venetist electoral politics, see [Liga Veneta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_Veneta "Liga Veneta") and [Elections in Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Veneto "Elections in Veneto").

Venetist ideas made a comeback in the 1960s, when the [Venetian Regionalist Autonomous Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_Regionalist_Autonomous_Movement&action=edit&redlink=1 "Venetian Regionalist Autonomous Movement (page does not exist)") (MARV) campaigned for the institution of the [ordinary regions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Italy#Regions_with_ordinary_statute "Regions of Italy") (including Veneto), prefigured by the Italian Constitution.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Toffano-34)[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-38) The ordinary regions were finally instituted in 1970.

Since the 1970s, Veneto experienced a dramatic economic boom due to a new production model based on small enterprises. The high burden of taxes and bureaucracy, associated with the increasing frustration with the inefficient and overstaffed Italian government in Rome, that continued to channel northern taxes as massive development aid to the corrupt and backward southern regions, was the key element, along with linguistic and historical claims, that led to the formation of [Liga Veneta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_Veneta "Liga Veneta") (LV) in January 1980.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Minahan-17) The opening speech of the first congress of the party in December 1979 recited: "Today for Venetians the moment has come, after 113 years of Italian unitary colonisation, to take their natural and human resources back, to fight against the wild exploitation that has brought emigration, pollution, and rooting out from their culture". [European integration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_integration "European integration") through the [European Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union "European Union") (EU) was seen as an opportunity to give back to Veneto its autonomy.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Francesco_Jori_2009,_pp._35,_41-33)[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-www1.lastampa.it-39)

One of the regional leaders of [Christian Democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democracy_(Italy) "Christian Democracy (Italy)") (DC), [Antonio Bisaglia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_Bisaglia "Antonio Bisaglia"), early understood Veneto's demand of more autonomy and that his party, the dominant force in [Venetian politics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_Veneto "Politics of Veneto") since 1946, would have been the main victim of the rise of LV as both parties competed for the support of the middle class. He thus proposed the evolution of the DC into a regional party on the model of the [Christian Social Union in Bavaria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Social_Union_in_Bavaria "Christian Social Union in Bavaria"). In 1982, Bisaglia tellingly declared, "Veneto would be mature for a federalist state, but this state, centralist and bureaucratic \[as it is\], will never concede autonomy to my region".[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-40) Opposition from Rome and Bisaglia's sudden death in 1984 stopped the plan of a regional DC on the "Bavarian model".[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-www1.lastampa.it-39)[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-41) [Giancarlo Galan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giancarlo_Galan "Giancarlo Galan"), regional leader of [Forza Italia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forza_Italia "Forza Italia") and [President of Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_Veneto "President of Veneto") from 1995 to 2010, made a similar proposal in 2008, taking example mainly from the [South Tyrolean People's Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Tyrolean_People%27s_Party "South Tyrolean People's Party"),[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-42)[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-43)[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-44) but his "Forza Veneto" remained just an idea.

The LV, whose leader in the 1980s and early 1990s was [Franco Rocchetta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franco_Rocchetta "Franco Rocchetta"), made its main electoral debut in the [1983 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_Italian_general_election_in_Veneto "1983 Italian general election in Veneto"), when it garnered 4.3% in Veneto, resulting in two elects to the [Italian Parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Parliament "Italian Parliament"). The party suffered many splits in its first decade of life and became a large political force only after its federation with other regional leagues, notably including [Umberto Bossi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umberto_Bossi "Umberto Bossi")'s [Lega Lombarda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lega_Lombarda "Lega Lombarda"), which resulted in [Lega Nord](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lega_Nord "Lega Nord") (LN) in 1991: in the [1996 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1996_Italian_general_election_in_Veneto "1996 Italian general election in Veneto"), the party was Veneto's largest with 29.3%. However, clashes between Bossi and hardcore Venetists led to several splits; in 1994, Rocchetta left in protest, but more damaging was the 1998 split led by [Fabrizio Comencini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fabrizio_Comencini "Fabrizio Comencini") and [Alessio Morosin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alessio_Morosin "Alessio Morosin"), who launched [Liga Veneta Repubblica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_Veneta_Repubblica "Liga Veneta Repubblica") (LVR). As a result, in the [2001 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_Italian_general_election_in_Veneto "2001 Italian general election in Veneto"), the LV garnered a mere 10.2% of the vote, its worst score since 1987, while the LVR gained 4.9%. As the latter faded, the LV returned to gain ground in the [2005 regional election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Venetian_regional_election "2005 Venetian regional election"), despite the meteoric success of [North-East Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North-East_Project "North-East Project") (PNE).[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-OE-45) More recently, a string of separatist parties, notably including [Venetian Independence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_Independence "Venetian Independence") (IV), emerged.

Both in 1992 and 2000 the Italian [Constitutional Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Italy "Constitutional Court of Italy") rejected proposals for an autonomy referendum, brought forward by the [Regional Council of Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Council_of_Veneto "Regional Council of Veneto").[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-mattinopadova.gelocal.it-46)[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-forumcostituzionale.it-47)

In the [2010 regional election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Venetian_regional_election "2010 Venetian regional election") the LV, in steady rise since 2001, was by far the largest party in the region with 35.2% of the vote, while its leader [Luca Zaia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luca_Zaia "Luca Zaia") was elected President of Veneto by a landslide 60.2%. The combined result of Venetist parties was 37.6%, the highest so far.[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-OE-45)

In the [2015 regional election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Venetian_regional_election "2015 Venetian regional election"), the LV set another record by winning 40.9% of the vote (combined result of party list, 17.8%, and Zaia's personal list, 23.1%) and Zaia was re-elected President of Veneto with 50.1% of the vote and a more coherently Venetist coalition. Separatist parties (Venetian Independence, [Independence We Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independence_We_Veneto "Independence We Veneto") and Veneto Confederal State) obtained 5.4% of the vote, while other regionalist and/or Venetist parties ( [Tosi List for Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tosi_List_for_Veneto "Tosi List for Veneto"), LTV's sponsored _Il Veneto del Fare_ list, [North-East Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North-East_Union "North-East Union"), and [Autonomous Veneto Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_Veneto_Autonomo "Liga Veneto Autonomo")) another 8.0% of the vote. Consequently, a majority of regional councillors adhered, at least to some extent, to Venetism.[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-48)

In the [2020 regional election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Venetian_regional_election "2020 Venetian regional election"), the LV set one more record by winning 61.5% of the vote (combined result of party list, 16.9%, and Zaia's personal list, 44.6%) and Zaia was re-elected President by a landslide 76.8% of the vote, more than any other candidate in any other region of Italy. Minor Venetist lists and parties (Venetian Autonomy List — sponsored by the LV and including [Liga Veneta Repubblica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_Veneta_Repubblica "Liga Veneta Repubblica") —, the [Party of Venetians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_of_Venetians_(2019) "Party of Venetians (2019)"), [Venetian Left](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_Left_(2013) "Venetian Left (2013)") and Veneto for the Autonomies) obtained a further 4.1% of the vote. As a result, 34 out of 51 seats in the Regional Council were controlled by Venetists, 33 by LV members.

## Recent developments

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Recent developments")\]

### 2012–2015 opinion polls on independence

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: 2012–2015 opinion polls on independence")\]

While support for a [federal system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federalism "Federalism"), as opposed to a centrally administered state, receives widespread consensus in Veneto, support for independence is less favoured. Recent polls show a rise of independentism. According to an opinion poll made in December 2011, 50% of Venetians support the independence of Veneto.[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-49) More strikingly, an opinion poll published on _[Il Gazzettino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Il_Gazzettino "Il Gazzettino")_ in January 2012 put those favoring independence at 53.3% (with the support from foreign-born Venetians at 55.0%).[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-50)[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-51) According to the same pollster, the support for independence rose to 56.7% in January 2013.[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-52)[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-53)

According to a February 2014 poll by Ixè, in a hypothetical referendum on independence, 47% of Venetians would vote yes and 26% no.[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-54) According to a March 2014 poll by [Ilvo Diamanti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ilvo_Diamanti "Ilvo Diamanti")'s Demos&Pi, 55% of Venetians favoured independence, 39% opposed it and the remaining 6% did not answer.[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-55)[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-56) According to a similar poll conducted by Istituto Piepoli, 64% of Venetians would vote in favour of more autonomy with 19% against, and 51% would vote for independence with 32% against.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-57) According to a Demos&Pi poll taken in October 2014, 53% of Venetians favoured independence, thus making Veneto the most separatist region in Italy, followed by [Sardinia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sardinia "Sardinia") (45%) and [Sicily](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sicily "Sicily") (44%).[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-58)[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-59) In March 2015 Demos&Pi found that 57% of Venetians (including 83% of [Liga Veneta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_Veneta "Liga Veneta")– [Lega Nord](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lega_Nord "Lega Nord")'s voters) favoured independence.[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-60)[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-61)

### Resolution 44/2012 on self-determination

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Resolution 44/2012 on self-determination")\]

In 2012 [Venetian Independence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_Independence "Venetian Independence") (IV), notably including [Lodovico Pizzati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lodovico_Pizzati "Lodovico Pizzati"), [Gianluca Busato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gianluca_Busato "Gianluca Busato") and [Alessio Morosin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alessio_Morosin "Alessio Morosin"), collected more than 20,000 signatures in support for a referendum on independence and presented them to President [Luca Zaia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luca_Zaia "Luca Zaia").[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-62)[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-63) Zaia informed the [Regional Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Council_of_Veneto "Regional Council of Veneto") and its President [Clodovaldo Ruffato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clodovaldo_Ruffato "Clodovaldo Ruffato") asked an opinion to the legal office,[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-64) which explained that such a referendum was not legal under the [Constitution of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy "Constitution of Italy").[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-65) On 6 October IV organised a march in Venice, during which it proposed a resolution (44/2012) for a consultative referendum on independence to be approved by the Regional Council: the text of the resolution was given to [Giovanni Furlanetto](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Giovanni_Furlanetto&action=edit&redlink=1 "Giovanni Furlanetto (page does not exist)"), LV regional councillor, who supported the proposition.[\[66\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-66)[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-67)[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-68) Another Council member, [Mariangelo Foggiato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mariangelo_Foggiato "Mariangelo Foggiato") of [North-East Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North-East_Union "North-East Union") (UNE), officially presented the resolution in the Council.[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-69)[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-70) On 17 October a total of 42 regional councillors out of 60 officially asked a discussion on the issue.[\[71\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-71)[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-72)[\[73\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-73)[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-74)

On 28 November the Council approved the resolution, in which "independence" was replaced by " [self-determination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-determination "Self-determination")", with 29 votes in favour, 2 against and 5 abstentions. Those in favour included Foggiato, LV's entire group, most councillors of [The People of Freedom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_People_of_Freedom "The People of Freedom"), [Pietrangelo Pettenò](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pietrangelo_Petten%C3%B2 "Pietrangelo Pettenò") of the [Communist Refoundation Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Refoundation_Party "Communist Refoundation Party")– [Federation of the Left](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federation_of_the_Left "Federation of the Left"), [Diego Bottacin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Bottacin "Diego Bottacin") of [Toward North](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toward_North "Toward North") and independent councillor [Sandro Sandri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandro_Sandri "Sandro Sandri"), who had expounded the resolution at the start of the session, while the entire group of the [Democratic Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Italy) "Democratic Party (Italy)") left the floor in protest, but proclaimed their support for a special statute for Veneto. The document required Zaia and Ruffato to urgently open talks with the [European Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union "European Union") (EU) and the [United Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") in order to come up with a referendum proposal that will establish the will of the Venetian people on its self-determination. To achieve this goal, the two Presidents would have benefited from the help of a special commission of jurists.[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-75)[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-76)[\[77\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-77)

### Petition to the EU and international support

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Petition to the EU and international support")\]

On 10 January 2013 a delegation of IV submitted to the [European Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission") in [Brussels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brussels "Brussels") a petition, signed by 50,000 European citizens, mainly Venetians, to endorse the referendum on self-determination.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-78) The collection of signatures for the petition was also supported by [Domà Nunch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dom%C3%A0_Nunch "Domà Nunch") in [Lombardy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lombardy "Lombardy").[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-79)[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-80) According to IV leaders, the EU should support the referendum and guarantee its result,[\[81\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-81) a notion which was contradicted by the attitudes of EU institutions toward the [2014 Scottish referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Scottish_independence_referendum "2014 Scottish independence referendum").

In March an appeal by international academics in support of resolution 44 was issued. The declaration, promoted by [Marco Bassani](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Luigi_Marco_Bassani&action=edit&redlink=1 "Luigi Marco Bassani (page does not exist)"), was signed by [Frank Van Dun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Van_Dun "Frank Van Dun"), [Hans-Hermann Hoppe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans-Hermann_Hoppe "Hans-Hermann Hoppe"), [Donald Livingston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Livingston "Donald Livingston"), [Ralph Raico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Raico "Ralph Raico"), [Xavier Sala-i-Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xavier_Sala-i-Martin "Xavier Sala-i-Martin"), and [Pascal Salin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascal_Salin "Pascal Salin"), along with [Paolo Bernardini](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Paolo_Bernardini&action=edit&redlink=1 "Paolo Bernardini (page does not exist)"), [Carlo Lottieri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlo_Lottieri "Carlo Lottieri") and [Alessandro Vitale](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Alessandro_Vitale&action=edit&redlink=1 "Alessandro Vitale (page does not exist)"). According to the appeal, "the self-determination process" of Veneto "will be an important step toward a better Europe and men of goodwill have to do everything possible to ensure that the electoral process leading to the independence referendum takes place without tension and with respect for all the people involved".[\[82\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-82) In Lombardy Bassani, Lottieri and several intellectuals around _L'Indipendenza_ newspaper formed the [Lombard Committee for Resolution 44](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lombard_Committee_for_Resolution_44 "Lombard Committee for Resolution 44").[\[83\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-83)[\[84\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-84)

### Further steps toward a referendum

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Further steps toward a referendum")\]

After a hunger strike by two members of IV, in March 2013 Zaia and Ruffato implemented the first step mandated by resolution 44 by appointing the special commission of jurists who would examine the referendum issue. The commission was composed of six experts, including IV's [Luca Azzano Cantarutti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luca_Azzano_Cantarutti "Luca Azzano Cantarutti").[\[85\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-85)[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-86)

On 2 April [Stefano Valdegamberi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefano_Valdegamberi "Stefano Valdegamberi"), floor leader of the [Union of the Centre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_of_the_Centre_(2002) "Union of the Centre (2002)"), who had abstained on Resolution 44 in November 2012, introduced a bill (342/2013) in order to call a referendum on independence by the end of the year.[\[87\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-87)[\[88\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-88)[\[89\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-89)[\[90\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-90)[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-91) By 7 June the bill was endorsed by more than 15 regional councillors, sufficient to convene a special session of the Council on the issue.[\[92\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-92)[\[93\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-93) The Council discussed it on 30 July and 17 September, but in both cases no decision was taken.[\[94\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-94)[\[95\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-95)

On 5 April [Castellavazzo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castellavazzo "Castellavazzo"), [Belluno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Belluno "Province of Belluno") (mayor: [Franco Roccon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franco_Roccon "Franco Roccon"), [The People of Freedom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_People_of_Freedom "The People of Freedom")) was the first municipality to pass a motion in support of bill 342.[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-96)[\[97\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-97)[\[98\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-98) Since then, more than 180 _[comuni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comune "Comune")_ (out of 581), led by mayors of different parties and representing about 1,800,000 Venetians (out of approximately 4,860,000), expressed their support for it; they notably include [Verona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verona "Verona"), [Rovigo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rovigo "Rovigo"), [Bassano del Grappa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bassano_del_Grappa "Bassano del Grappa"), [Castelfranco Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castelfranco_Veneto "Castelfranco Veneto"), [Vittorio Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vittorio_Veneto "Vittorio Veneto"), [Arzignano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arzignano "Arzignano"), [Legnago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legnago "Legnago"), [Montebelluna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montebelluna "Montebelluna"), [Jesolo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesolo "Jesolo"), [Montecchio Maggiore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montecchio_Maggiore "Montecchio Maggiore"), [Oderzo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oderzo "Oderzo") and [Cittadella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cittadella "Cittadella"). Among provinces, [Padua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Padua "Province of Padua"), [Verona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Verona "Province of Verona"), [Treviso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Treviso "Province of Treviso") and [Venice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Venice "Province of Venice"), for a total of about 3,510,000 inhabitants, endorsed the bill.[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-99)[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-100)

In February 2014 Liga Veneta–Lega Nord launched its own campaign for a referendum on independence.[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-101)[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-102)

On 1 April 2014 a committee of the Regional Council put forward bills calling for a referendum on independence and on more autonomy for the region. The move was supported by the representatives of Liga Veneta, [Forza Italia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forza_Italia_(2013) "Forza Italia (2013)") (the minority faction), [New Centre-Right](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Centre-Right "New Centre-Right"), [Popular Future](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_Future "Popular Future"), Union of the Centre and North-East Union, with the opposition of the Democratic Party, [Italy of Values](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy_of_Values "Italy of Values") and the Federation of the Left.[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-consiglioveneto-103)[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-corriere2-104) The day after, all the floor leaders of the parties (but the federation of the left) represented in the council officially asked the Italian government to give Veneto the status of a [special-statute autonomous region](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_regions_with_special_statute "Autonomous regions with special statute") and fiscal autonomy.[\[105\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-consiglioveneto2-105) The final document was approved by Liga Veneta, Forza Italia (both fations), New Centre Right, Union of the Centre, Italy of Values and North-East Union.[\[106\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-consiglioveneto3-106)

On 10 June the Regional Council discussed and passed a law concerning five referendum questions concerning special autonomy. On 12 June the same legislative assembly passed Valdegamberi's bill 342/2013 in order to hold a referendum on the independence (question: "Do you want Veneto to become a sovereign and independent republic?") with 30 yeas, 12 nays and 3 abstentions.[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-107) A year later the [Constitutional Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Italy "Constitutional Court of Italy") ruled the independence referendum out as contrary to the [Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy "Constitution of Italy"), but authorised one of the five autonomy referendums ("Do you want the Region of Veneto to be granted of further forms and special conditions of autonomy?").[\[108\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-108)[\[109\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-109) The event was unique as the Court had previously rejected proposals for similar referendums brought forward by the Regional Council of Veneto.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-mattinopadova.gelocal.it-46)[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-forumcostituzionale.it-47)

### Online referendum on independence

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Online referendum on independence")\]

Main article: [2014 Venetian independence referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Venetian_independence_referendum "2014 Venetian independence referendum")

[Plebiscite 2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plebiscito.eu "Plebiscito.eu") (P2013), a non-partisan committee organised _Plebiscito.eu_, an online [independence referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Venetian_independence_referendum "2014 Venetian independence referendum"), with no official recognition, for 16–21 March.[\[110\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-110)[\[111\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-111)[\[112\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-112) P2013 had been launched by a group of splinters from IV, led by Lodovico Pizzati and Gianluca Busato, in July 2013.

According to _Plebiscito.eu'_ s staff, 2.36 million Venetians (63.2% of all eligible voters) participated in the online referendum and 89.1% of them (that is to say 56.6% of all eligible voters) voted yes.[\[113\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Plebiscito.eu-results-113)[\[114\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-RischioCalcolato-114) This was enough for P2013 to proclaim Veneto's independence from Italy in [Treviso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treviso "Treviso") on the night of 21 March.[\[115\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-115)[\[116\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-116)[\[117\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-117) Voters approved also the adoption of the [Euro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euro "Euro") (51.4% yes), EU membership (55.7% yes) and [NATO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO "NATO") membership (64.5% yes).[\[113\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Plebiscito.eu-results-113)[\[114\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-RischioCalcolato-114)

The event was covered by several international media. During an interview with foreign journalists on 19 March, President Zaia announced that he too had voted (yes) in the poll, promised that he would bring bill 342 again to the discussion of the Regional Council and explained that he would seek "total independence" for Veneto.[\[118\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-118)[\[119\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-119)[\[120\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-120)

On 28 April, during a visit in Veneto, Minister of Interior [Angelino Alfano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angelino_Alfano "Angelino Alfano") acknowledged that "there is a Venetian question, which will be central in the government's relation with regions". In reference to what he called "Agenda Veneto", he said: "We think that Veneto could be the laboratory for a form of strong and advanced federalism. \[...\] We cannot close our eyes in front of independentist risings. \[...\] The answer is dual: enhancing autonomy and improving the government's services". For his part, Zaia explained to Alfano the "legitimate request of Venetians" for autonomy and independence, and that "the issue of autonomy and the desire of independence of Venetians cannot be resolved with an aspirin", concluding that "if Rome continues to sleep, it is inevitable that Veneto will organise by itself".[\[121\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-corriere3-121)[\[122\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-ilgazzettino-122)

### Autonomy referendum and negotiation

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Autonomy referendum and negotiation")\]

Main article: [2017 Venetian autonomy referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Venetian_autonomy_referendum "2017 Venetian autonomy referendum")

In March 2016 President Zaia announced that he had written to [Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Italy "Prime Minister of Italy") [Matteo Renzi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matteo_Renzi "Matteo Renzi") in order to start the negotiation both on the organisation of the referendum on autonomy and the devolution of further powers to Veneto according to article 116 of the Constitution.[\[123\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-123) Zaia proposed the referendum to be held on the very same day of the [2016 constitutional referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Italian_constitutional_referendum "2016 Italian constitutional referendum") (which would reduce the regions' powers—article 117, while expanding the powers that can be devolved to regions according to article 116 and creating a regionalised Senate), a notion deemed legally impossible by undersecretary [Gianclaudio Bressa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gianclaudio_Bressa "Gianclaudio Bressa"),[\[124\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-124) and the negotiation started in May.[\[125\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-125)[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-126)

According to an opinion poll taken in June, 78.5% of Venetians would take part to the autonomy referendum, 78.4% would vote yes, 3.5% no and 18.1% did not know. According to the same poll, 70.7% of voters would participate also in the constitutional referendum, 41.3% would vote yes, 22.2% no and 36.5% did not know.[\[127\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-127)[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-128)

Contextually, two bills calling for an independence referendum were introduced in the Regional Council, one by Liga Veneta's [Marino Finozzi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marino_Finozzi "Marino Finozzi"), [Gabriele Michieletto](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gabriele_Michieletto&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gabriele Michieletto (page does not exist)"), [Alessandro Montagnoli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alessandro_Montagnoli "Alessandro Montagnoli") and [Luciano Sandonà](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Luciano_Sandon%C3%A0&action=edit&redlink=1 "Luciano Sandonà (page does not exist)"),[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-129) with the support of [Roberto Ciambetti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Ciambetti "Roberto Ciambetti") (President of the Council),[\[130\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-130)[\[131\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-131)[\[132\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-132) and the other by [Antonio Guadagnini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_Guadagnini "Antonio Guadagnini").[\[133\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-133)

In April 2017 Zaia announced that the [autonomy referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Venetian_autonomy_referendum "2017 Venetian autonomy referendum") would take place on 22 October,[\[134\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-134)[\[135\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-135) along with a similar [referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Lombard_autonomy_referendum "2017 Lombard autonomy referendum") in [Lombardy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lombardy "Lombardy").[\[136\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-136) 57.2% of Venetians participated in the referendum and 98.1% voted "yes". Consequently, [President of Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_Veneto "President of Veneto") [Luca Zaia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luca_Zaia "Luca Zaia") started a negotiation with the Italian government.

## People and movements

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_nationalism&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: People and movements")\]

In November 2009 the _Corriere del Veneto_, the regional edition of the _[Corriere della Sera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corriere_della_Sera "Corriere della Sera")_ in Veneto, published a broad overview of what it described as "Venetist galaxy". The newspaper counted around 20 notable Venetist organisations: along the four major Venetist parties of the time (Liga Veneta–Lega Nord, [Liga Veneta Repubblica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_Veneta_Repubblica "Liga Veneta Repubblica"), [North-East Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North-East_Project "North-East Project") and [Venetian National Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_National_Party "Venetian National Party")), a large variety of minor political parties, movements, cultural associations and trade unions were listed.[\[137\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-137)

A prominent Venetist cultural association is _[Raixe Venete](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raixe_Venete "Raixe Venete")_ (Venetian Roots), which organises every year the well-known _Festa dei Veneti_[\[138\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-138) in [Cittadella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cittadella "Cittadella").[\[139\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-139)[\[140\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-140) The association has strong links with separatists from all over Europe and especially from the [Basque Country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basque_Country_(autonomous_community) "Basque Country (autonomous community)"). At the _Festa dei Veneti_, Venetists of every political colour, politicians of different political parties (including non-Venetist, both right and left), Venetist associations, actors, comedians, flag-wavers, musicians (notably including [Herman Medrano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_Medrano "Herman Medrano")), rock bands, and many people meet at the beginning of September every year.[\[141\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-141) In November 2009 _Raixe Venete_ organised a demonstration in Venice in support of the teaching of Venetian in schools: a wide range of people took part, from [Roberto Ciambetti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Ciambetti "Roberto Ciambetti"), leader of Liga Veneta–Lega Nord in the [Regional Council of Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Council_of_Veneto "Regional Council of Veneto"), to [Luca Casarini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luca_Casarini "Luca Casarini"), a former far-left [anti-globalisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-globalization_movement "Anti-globalization movement") activist and leader of the _[Tute Bianche](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tute_Bianche "Tute Bianche")_ in Veneto.[\[142\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-142)

The [European Federalist Free Entrepreneurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Federalist_Free_Entrepreneurs "European Federalist Free Entrepreneurs") (LIFE) was formed in 1994 by a group of Venetist entrepreneurs (Fabio Padovan, [Diego Cancian](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Diego_Cancian&action=edit&redlink=1 "Diego Cancian (page does not exist)"), etc.) who opposed the "fiscal and bureaucratic oppression" of the "Venetian people" by Italy and demanded [fiscal federalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiscal_federalism "Fiscal federalism") and autonomy for the region. In particular, they decided to organise themselves as a trade union, saying that they were the most oppressed workers in Italy.[\[143\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-143)

Another notable association is [Venetians Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetians_Movement "Venetians Movement")[\[144\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-I_Veneti-144) and was founded in 2006 by [Patrik Riondato](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Patrik_Riondato&action=edit&redlink=1 "Patrik Riondato (page does not exist)"). Initially it presented itself as a cross-party political movement which aimed to promote independence in a democratic and nonviolent way. However, in 2010 it took part to the founding of the [Party of the Venetians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_of_the_Venetians "Party of the Venetians"), a coalition of Venetist parties ranging from the centre-right to the far-left, which was later merged into [Veneto State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veneto_State "Veneto State").[\[145\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-145)

Among the youth, the strongest organisation is [Independentist Youth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independentist_Youth "Independentist Youth"), whose most representative figures are [Giacomo Mirto](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Giacomo_Mirto&action=edit&redlink=1 "Giacomo Mirto (page does not exist)") and [Stefano Danieli](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Stefano_Danieli&action=edit&redlink=1 "Stefano Danieli (page does not exist)").[\[146\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-146)

In the midst of the above-mentioned campaign for a referendum on independence, two non-party committees were launched: [Plebiscite 2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plebiscito.eu "Plebiscito.eu") and [Let Veneto Decide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Il_Veneto_Decida "Il Veneto Decida") (later supplanted by United for Independent Veneto/We Independent Veneto/ [Independence We Veneto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independence_We_Veneto "Independence We Veneto"), which in turn became an electoral coalition of parties). [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/60/Veneto_is_not_Italy.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Veneto_is_not_Italy.jpg)"We are a nation, Veneto is not Italy", a campaign for the 2009 local elections.

The first Venetist party in Veneto was **Lion of Saint Mark** ( _Leone di San Marco_), active from 1921 to 1924 and commonly described as the forerunner of Venetian nationalist parties.[\[160\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Jori-160) It was founded by [Italico Corradino Cappellotto](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Italico_Corradino_Cappellotto&action=edit&redlink=1 "Italico Corradino Cappellotto (page does not exist)"), a member of the [Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Kingdom_of_Italy) "Chamber of Deputies (Kingdom of Italy)") for the [Italian People's Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_People%27s_Party_(1919) "Italian People's Party (1919)"). The party participated in the [1921 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1921_Italian_general_election "1921 Italian general election") in the constituencies of the provinces of [Treviso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Treviso "Province of Treviso") and [Venice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Venice "Province of Venice"), winning 6.1% of the vote in the province of Treviso and scoring around 20% in the very rural areas that would become the heartland of [Liga Veneta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_Veneta "Liga Veneta") sixty years later.[\[160\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-Jori-160)[\[161\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-161)[\[162\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-162)[\[163\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venetian_nationalism#cite_note-163) The party was suppressed by [Italian Fascism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Fascism "Italian Fascism"), along all the other parties.

Another Venetist party was the [Venetian Regionalist Autonomous Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venetian_Regionalist_Autonomous_Movement&action=edit&redlink=1 "Venetian Regionalist Autonomous Movement (page does not exist)") (MARV), a cultural-political association, which was active in the 1960s. The first organised Venetist parties were started only after the institution of Veneto as Region and the direct election of the [Regional Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Council_of_Veneto "Regional Council of Veneto") in 1970.

Some Venetian parties campaign for federal reform, others for autonomy or a special statute for Veneto, others for an autonomous North-East region including Veneto, [Friuli-Venezia Giulia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friuli-Venezia_Giulia "Friuli-Venezia Giulia") and [Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trentino-Alto_Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol "Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol"), some others for outright independence.
